content.raw:
I have named each polygon mesh as the name of its parent visual, should there be a name field associated explicitly with polylines? This might make things simpler on the physics side too. I am working on things to get evrything to work properly, but for creating meshes using PolyLineShape.cc, the naming is an issue. How should I handle this? 
Also, I'm trying to figure out the rendering error that I have been facing with respect to the normals.
content.html: I have named each polygon mesh as the name of its parent visual, should there be a name field associated explicitly with polylines? This might make things simpler on the physics side too. I am working on things to get evrything to work properly, but for creating meshes using PolyLineShape.cc, the naming is an issue. How should I handle this? Also, I'm trying to figure out the rendering error that I have been facing with respect to the normals.

Currently GTS is not a required dependency for gazebo (for example MeshCSG files are only compiled if HAVE_GTS is true).

I initially didn't have gts installed and it caused a compilation failure, so we need to resolve this.

@nkoenig should we consider requiring GTS, or should we make the PolyLineShape partially supported?

content.raw: I wonder if this class could derive from MeshShape? It would be nice if it could generate a MeshShape, so that we don't have to create PolyLineShapes for each physics engine (ie. ODEPolyLineShape, BulletPolyLineShape). What do you think @nkoenig ?
content.html: I wonder if this class could derive from MeshShape? It would be nice if it could generate a MeshShape, so that we don't have to create PolyLineShapes for each physics engine (ie. ODEPolyLineShape, BulletPolyLineShape). What do you think @nkoenig ?

content.raw: Unfortunately, we can't inherit from MeshShape. I'm looking into a way to prevent code duplication, but right now I think every engine will have to create a PolylineShape.
content.html: Unfortunately, we can't inherit from MeshShape. I'm looking into a way to prevent code duplication, but right now I think every engine will have to create a PolylineShape.

content.raw: My solution has been to make a ODEMesh helper class that both ODEPolyLineShape and ODEMeshShape use. I'll update Bullet, Simbody, and DART to use something similar.
content.html: My solution has been to make a ODEMesh helper class that both ODEPolyLineShape and ODEMeshShape use. I'll update Bullet, Simbody, and DART to use something similar.

content.raw: I'm discussing this with @iche033 and he is suggesting that we could create a separate file for all the GTS related code. The motivation for this is that we're starting to duplicate code from many places. Can you create a new file called `GTSMeshUtil` and start by populating it with `FillVertex`, `FillFace`, `add_constraint` and `CreateExtrudedPolyline`? In MeshManager::CreateExtrudedPolyline, you should just call GTSMeshUtil::CreateExtrudedPolyline. Don't forget to use #ifdefs to compile `GTSMeshUtil` only when GTS is installed.
content.html: I'm discussing this with @iche033 and he is suggesting that we could create a separate file for all the GTS related code. The motivation for this is that we're starting to duplicate code from many places. Can you create a new file called GTSMeshUtil and start by populating it with FillVertex, FillFace, add_constraint and CreateExtrudedPolyline? In MeshManager::CreateExtrudedPolyline, you should just call GTSMeshUtil::CreateExtrudedPolyline. Don't forget to use #ifdefs to compile GTSMeshUtil only when GTS is installed.

content.raw:
Several comments:

* Quite a few new code added and no automatic test created to go through it. Any chance of adding some tests, specially for new created classes?
* Extensive use of raw pointers. Any reason not to use shared pointers? There are probably some memory leaks, check the ```new``` commands and see if the memory was released when leaving the scope.
* Some of the code added in this pull request is commented. Any reason to do it?

Thanks.
content.html:
Several comments:

  • Quite a few new code added and no automatic test created to go through it. Any chance of adding some tests, specially for new created classes?
  • Extensive use of raw pointers. Any reason not to use shared pointers? There are probably some memory leaks, check the new commands and see if the memory was released when leaving the scope.
  • Some of the code added in this pull request is commented. Any reason to do it?

Thanks.

content.raw:
A test has been added for polyline.

There are some raw pointers when using submeshes. A fix for this would touch a signification portion of Gazebo, and should be saved for a different pull request.

The comments code has been uncommented or removed.
content.html:
A test has been added for polyline.

There are some raw pointers when using submeshes. A fix for this would touch a signification portion of Gazebo, and should be saved for a different pull request.

The comments code has been uncommented or removed.

content.raw: This pull request is ready for review. Polyline shapes should work for ODE, Bullet, and DART.
content.html: This pull request is ready for review. Polyline shapes should work for ODE, Bullet, and DART.

content.html: Thanks for fixing it; I like how the mesh classes are split up.

content.raw:
Note that GTS is required for the polyline shapes. For osx home-brew users, I had a linking error that I fixed with the following:
~~~
export LIBRARY_PATH=${LIBRARY_PATH}:/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib
~~~
(gettext is a dependency of gts)
content.html:
Note that GTS is required for the polyline shapes. For osx home-brew users, I had a linking error that I fixed with the following:

export LIBRARY_PATH=${LIBRARY_PATH}:/usr/local/opt/gettext/lib

(gettext is a dependency of gts)

content.raw: We shouldn't hard-code any physics engine name in case they are not installed. We can use macro `PHYSICS_ENGINE_VALUES` instead of the `::testing::Values()` statement. Then if simbody is installed, we abort the test with an error message with a link to the relevant issue (#883). At least that's what we do with the other physics tests.
content.html: We shouldn't hard-code any physics engine name in case they are not installed. We can use macro PHYSICS_ENGINE_VALUES instead of the ::testing::Values() statement. Then if simbody is installed, we abort the test with an error message with a link to the relevant issue (#883). At least that's what we do with the other physics tests.

add these two lines for the normals to generate properly

  if (subMesh->GetNormalCount() != subMesh->GetVertexCount())
    subMesh->SetNormalCount(subMesh->GetVertexCount());

+1

diff -r 4515edf540dd gazebo/common/MeshManager.cc
--- a/gazebo/common/MeshManager.cc  Wed Jul 02 12:08:19 2014 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/common/MeshManager.cc  Tue Jul 08 01:04:58 2014 -0700
@@ -600,6 +600,8 @@
     subMesh->AddIndex(i*2+3+numSides*2);
   }

+  if (subMesh->GetNormalCount() != subMesh->GetVertexCount())
+    subMesh->SetNormalCount(subMesh->GetVertexCount());
   subMesh->RecalculateNormals();
 }
